results.abstract: Letter from former astronaut Wally Schirra comments on July 22 article about NASA's mission statement
results.snippet: To the Editor:      Re ''NASA's Goals Delete Mention of Home Planet'' (front page, July 22): My theme when I ran an environmental company after leaving the space program was, and still is: ''I left Earth three times, and found no other place to go....
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''NASA's Goals Delete Mention of Home Planet'' (front page, July 22): My theme when I ran an environmental company after leaving the space program was, and still is: ''I left Earth three times, and found no other place to go. Please take care of Spaceship Earth.'' Wally Schirra Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., July 22, 2006 The writer was an astronaut on the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo missions.

results.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column discusses Barcelona soccer team and its star player Ronaldinho; photo (M)

headline.main: Perpetually on the Road, Branding Barcelona

results.snippet: The phenomenon named Ronaldinho and his Barcelona club continue their North American tour against the Red Bulls in Bruce Arena’s first match as coach.
results.lead_paragraph: NEVER let it be said that soccer players do not work hard for their millions. Barely a month after the final head butt of the World Cup, the best players in the world are wandering around North America in search of their legs and Yankee dollars, not necessarily in that order.

results.abstract: Visa Signature, American Express Platinum and MasterCard Premium offer access to special events as way to lure consumers to sign up for premium credit cards; perks are increasingly taking form of unique experiences rather than products and services that no longer entice shoppers; customers often pay high prices for events, but access is limited to members; photos (M)

headline.main: Holding Liev Schreiber's Tony Award? Priceless

results.snippet: Credit card companies are vying for customers with the lure of experiences, from behind-the-scenes access at the Tonys to seats on simulated spaceflights.
results.lead_paragraph: BILL POWELL, a retired Pennsylvania Lottery employee, was in line at the bar at a party after the Tony Awards ceremony last year when the man ahead of him turned around and asked for help so he could carry drinks to his friends. ''It was Liev Schreiber asking me to hold the Tony he'd just won,'' said Mr. Powell, still marveling over the encounter with the actor, whose award-winning role was in the revival of ''Glengarry Glen Ross.''

results.abstract: Robin Marantz Henig article on research suggesting that microorganisms may be factor in obesity--along with genetics, overeating and lack of exercise; notes work by Jeffrey Gordon on bacteria in gut that extract nutrients from what we eat and Richard Atkinson's and Nikhil Dhurandhar's research on viruses and other pathogens that may infect body; notes their hopes that research will eventually lead to new strategies for treating obesity; photos (L)
results.snippet: It’s clear that diet and genes contribute to how fat you are. But a new wave of scientific research suggests that, for some people, there might be a third factor  microorganisms.
results.lead_paragraph: In the 30-plus years that Richard Atkinson has been studying obesity, he has always maintained that overeating doesn't really explain it all. His epiphany came early in his career, when he was a medical fellow at U.C.L.A. engaged in a study of people who weighed more than 300 pounds and had come in for obesity surgery. ''The general thought at the time was that fat people ate too much,'' Atkinson, now at Virginia Commonwealth University, told me recently. ''And we documented that fat people do eat too much -- our subjects ate an average of 6,700 calories a day. But what was so impressive to me was the fact that not all fat people eat too much.''

results.abstract: Kevin Coyne Jersey column on racial tensions that arose in Edison, NJ, after Indian immigrant Rajnikant Parikh was arrested for striking police officer; police were there to disperse crowd that gathered to set off firecrackers; newly elected Mayor Jun Choi, son of Korean immigrants, comments on situation; photo (M)

headline.main: Even After Race Is Won, Race Is Still the Issue

results.snippet: Edison's Indian population helped elect the first Asian mayor for the New Jersey city, and he now has the difficult task of calming recent racial fires.
results.lead_paragraph: TODAY this township's young new mayor -- born in Seoul, schooled at M.I.T. and Columbia, the victor over a three-term incumbent -- plans to don a Hindustani robe called a kurta and march alongside a Bollywood star in a parade observing India Day, the 59th anniversary of the country's independence. The route is scheduled to go past sari shops, Indian banquet halls and an apartment complex where an arrest by a white police officer a few weeks ago spiraled into protests that culminated with epithets like ''cockroaches'' flying outside the municipal building. New Jersey is a complicated place.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Florida: Astronaut Lets A Name Slip

results.snippet: An American astronaut let slip that the name of the new vehicle that NASA hopes will take astronauts back to the moon will be Orion. The name was supposed to be a secret until next week. But the astronaut, Col. Jeffrey N. Williams, taping a message...
results.lead_paragraph: An American astronaut let slip that the name of the new vehicle that NASA hopes will take astronauts back to the moon will be Orion. The name was supposed to be a secret until next week. But the astronaut, Col. Jeffrey N. Williams, taping a message for NASA from the International Space Station, said, ''We've been calling it the crew exploration vehicle for several years, but today it has a name, Orion.'' The message was transmitted accidentally over space-to-ground radio.

results.abstract: Vickie Kloeris, head of National Aeronautics and Space Administration space food program, describes culinary changes that provide better flavor and variety for astronauts serving on International Space Station; discusses challenges in developing food for planned expeditions to Mars; photo (M)

headline.main: Taking Humdrum Astronaut Food, and Kicking It Up a Notch

results.snippet: Food scientists in Houston spend their days worrying like fussy mothers over what their astronauts eat.
results.lead_paragraph: The first rule about cooking for astronauts is don't make anything that crumbles. No one wants to chase a crumb around a space station. Although most people rarely consider what the three people who live on the International Space Station are going to have for dinner, food scientists in Houston spend their days worrying like fussy mothers over what their astronauts eat.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students will brainstorm about how their favorite foods might be converted to astronaut food. They will explore the history of food science and food trends within American culture, as well as within NASA. To conclude, students will create their own NASA specific menus based on current technology trends.

byline.original: By MARCELLA RUNELL and KATHERINE SCHULTEN

results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
